    Alice Wilson

    Social anthropologist, with research interests in the political and economic anthropology of the Middle East and North Africa.

    • Sussex University
    • Google Scholar

    Books

    Afterlives of revolution: Everyday Counterhistories in southern Oman

    March 01, 2023

    Stanford University Press

    This book is explores sovereignty and state power through the case of a liberation movement that set out to make itself into a state.

    Chapter pp. 134-153: The Everyday Lives of Sovereignty

    June 15, 2020

    Cornell University Press

    Critical reinterpretations of kinship studies questioned earlier ideas that kinship relations reflect and reproduce a dominant social order. ‘New’ kinship studies have nevertheless shown.

    Chapter pp. 143-163: Keeping up with the times: the growth in support from non-state actors for the Polisario Front liberation movement

    June 15, 2020

    Social currents in the Maghreb - London, Hurst

    How does an armed liberation movement cultivate support from different actors over changing historical contexts?

    Chapter pp. 142-163: o compensate or not to compensate? Law, property and Sahrawi refugees in Algeria

    February 15, 2020

    Law and property in Algeria: anthropological perspectives

    Corced migration often leads to refugees’ dispossession, and thus to refugees’ pursuit of various strategies to try and gain access to property, from home or in the new living space.

    Chapter pp. 134-153: Poursuivre la révolution: une perspective depuis les camps de réfugiés sahraouis

    October 11, 2018

    Presses Universitaires François-Rabelais de Tours

    Revolutions create exceptional contexts of liminality during which militants undertake extraordinary actions in the pursuit of social, political and economic transformations.

    Chapter: For us, Parliament is a Tool for Liberation

    October 11, 2017

    London, Palgrave

    Revolutions create exceptional contexts of liminality during which militants undertake extraordinary actions in the pursuit of social, political and economic transformations.

    Sovereignty in Exile: a Saharan liberation

    October 10, 2016

    University of Pennsylvania Press

    This book is explores sovereignty and state power through the case of a liberation movement that set out to make itself into a state.

    Chapter: Elecciones transterritoriales: los votantes saharauis en los campamentos de refugiados y más allá

    January 01, 2016

    Madrid, Catarata

    Elections are important tools not only of governance but also of nation-building and international diplomacy. This chapter examines how elections can be adapted for such goals in the absence of a conventional nation-state setting.

    Chapter: Going under the radar in Western Sahara

    September 28, 2015

    London, Routledge

    The case for decolonization in Western Sahara hinges upon the right of the people of the territory to self-determination. Yet during four decades of Morocco and Western Sahara’s liberation movement vying for sovereignty over the territory, and two decades of UN attempts at conflict resolution, a political stalemate has taken hold which has left the people of Western Sahara all too often overlooked in their own conflict.

    Chapter:Comment sont organisées les élections dans les camps de réfugiés.

    January 01, 2015

    London, Routledge

    This chapter examines the forms and stakes of elections in the Sahrawi refugee camps (French).

    Chapter: Cycles of crisis, migration and the formation of new political identities in Western Sahara.

    June 01, 2012

    London, Routledge

    This paper considers how conjunctions of crisis and migration are productive in a Foucauldian sense.
